title: 'Anarchy': Call for action over e-bike gangs
text:
A gang of teenagers on e-bikes have been captured hooning down streets and even a golf club on

Sydney's

title: What it's like to play the world number one at the Australian Open
text:
After reaching a career-high ranking of 74 three months ago, Adam Walton had reason to believe he could cause an upset or two at the Australian Open.

That was until the men's main draw was released last week and the 26-year-old Australian discovered the identity of his first-round opponent: world number one Carlos Alcaraz.

Australian Open: day two blog The Australian Open continues on day two, with Alex de Minaur among the local hopes taking to the court at Melbourne Park.

If Walton was to advance to the second round of the Australian Open for the first time, he was going to have play at a level well beyond his current ranking of 81.

Far from being embarrassed by a player who has won six majors, Walton gave a solid account of himself in the 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-2 defeat to Alcaraz on Rod Laver Arena on Sunday evening.

Rather than be disappointed with his performance, Walton appreciated the opportunity to face the Spaniard, who is tipped to be remembered as one of the greats of the game.

So, what is it like to play Alcaraz?

"For Alcaraz, I think he moves a bit different to the rest of the guys on the tour," Walton said.

"He has that extra venom on the short balls and on the balls that sit up a little bit more.

"Anytime he can get set on a forehand, he hits it at a different speed that I'm not used to.

"Obviously, I don't get that exposure week in, week out.

"It's just really cool to have shared the court on Rod Laver with him tonight."

Adam Walton gave a solid account of himself against the world number one. (Getty Images: Shi Tang)

Walton acknowledged he learned what separates the best from the rest.

"I played pretty well," Walton said.

"I thought I served well. I guess he was a little bit better at some moments than I was."

'A difficult match'

Alacaraz had defeated Walton when they first met last year, winning in straight sets on grass in the third round of Queen's.

There were tricky moments for the reigning French and US Open champion on Sunday, with Walton breaking his serve during the second set.

Adam Walton (left) gained the respect of Carlos Alcaraz following their match. (AP: Dita Alangkara)

After the match, Alcaraz was full of praise for Walton.

"It was, I would say, a difficult match for me," Alcaraz said.

"In the first set, just one break … I think he was playing really good, really solid. I think he was trying to find the position to attack every time he can.

"Then, the second set I think he found more spots to be aggressive … it was then more complicated for me."

Alcaraz, who has never been past the quarterfinals at Melbourne Park, now turns his attention to his next opponent, Germany's Yannick Hanfmann.

For Walton, he will have to wait another year before he gets the chance to advance from the first round at his home major.

But he still walks away with memories he will cherish for the rest of his career.

"To be able to play on a big court against a big player, and especially at home to play on Rod Laver, I think that's a moment I will never forget," Walton said.

title: Calls to tax super-rich more as number of global billionaires hits record
text:
Australia has 48 billionaires who hold more wealth than the bottom 40 per cent of the population combined, a new report by Oxfam Australia has found.

It says that with eight new billionaires added to Forbes's Australian billionaires list since 2020, they are now wealthier than almost 11 million Australians, with more than one third of those — or 3.7 million people — living in poverty according to the latest Poverty in Australia 2025 report by the Australian Council of Social Service and UNSW.

And it is a global trend, Oxfam asserts, with the number of billionaires around the world passing 3,000 for the first time, with a combined wealth of $27.7 trillion. That figure is based on Forbes's global list of billionaires.

The report, Resisting the Rule of the Rich: Defending Freedom Against Billionaire Power, calls for a net wealth tax on the richest 0.5 per cent of households, with tax rates higher in line with increased wealth.

The Swiss ski resort of Davos hosts the 56th edition of the World Economic Forum this week. (Reuters: Denis Balibouse)

Its release coincides with Monday's opening of the 2026 World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. The five-day event — the 56th edition — will host more than 3,000 participants from 130 countries, including 65 heads of state.

A 5 per cent wealth tax on Australia’s billionaires just last year could have raised $17.4 billion, Oxfam says, enough to deliver cheap childcare for all families, extend energy bill relief for another two years, and increase the humanitarian budget almost seven times over.

Oxfam Australia CEO Jennifer Tierney said what the organisation was advocating for was a "stronger tax system".

"Adding an additional 5 per cent to the tax would mean another $17 billion for ... things like childcare and housing ... as one in three Australians has faced food insecurity over the last year," Ms Tierney told the ABC.

" The gap between those doing it toughest and those benefiting most is stark, and well evidenced. "

Billionaire wealth in Australia is growing by almost $600,000 a day, Oxfam said.

Jennifer Tierney says the organisation is advocating for a "stronger tax system". (Supplied: Oxfam)

Concerns over democracy threatened

Ms Tierney said there was a correlation between inequity and inequality in a country and the vibrancy of its democracy.

91 millionaires paid no tax, ATO stats reveal There were 91 Australians who earned more than $1 million in total income yet paid no tax in 2022-23, new Australian Taxation Office (ATO) shows.

"The more and more the wealthy control politics or have influence over politics, the erosion partly because people push back and rise up and understand that they're not actually benefiting from the system that the government is putting in place.

"There becomes a tension and a lack of trust in democracy."

The report also notes the second US presidency of Donald Trump has come at the same time as a rapid rise in billionaires worldwide.

Billionaire fortunes have grown three times faster than the average annual rate in the previous five years since the electoral victory of Donald Trump in November 2024, it said.

Tesla CEO Elon Musk — the world's richest man, who was integral to Mr Trump's campaign success and the first weeks of the president's second term — became the first billionaire to briefly surpass half a trillion dollars, the report found.

South African-born Elon Musk, who promised massive cuts in US federal spending, is the world's richest man. (Reuters: Nathan Howard)

"Whilst US billionaires have seen the sharpest growth in their fortunes, billionaires in the rest of the world have also seen double-digit increases," the report said.

" Actions of the Trump presidency, including the championing of deregulation and undermining agreements to increase corporate taxation, have benefited the richest around the world. "

Enjoying abundant riches meant greater access to power, Oxfam says, with billionaires estimated to be 4,000 times more likely to hold political office than ordinary citizens around the world.

The super rich are then able, it argued, to shape the rules of our economies and societies to their greater financial benefit, sometimes to the detriment of the rights and freedoms of people around the world.

It also argues economic inequality plays a major role in the erosion of rights and political freedoms.

Calls to end property tax breaks

In addition to a wealth tax, Oxfam is calling for a phasing out of negative gearing to close loopholes that allow wealthy individuals pay less tax — plus an end to capital gains tax discounts for individuals and trusts.

Rental market remains at record highs Australia's rental market is "starting to rebalance" with prices flat in some capital cities but affordability remains a concern, according to property portal Domain.

The capital gains tax discount is a 50 per cent discount on the tax paid when people sell an asset, like a property, if they have held that asset for more than 12 months.

Negative gearing is the ability to deduct losses on an asset (such as expenses associated with renting out an apartment) from other taxable income, which allows people to lower their tax.

The introduction of the discount coincided with a rapid increase in the use of negative gearing because, together, they encourage investment in property to secure capital gains that are taxed at concessional rates while also enabling investors to deduct losses.

The report also found that the wealth divide had increased dramatically since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.

"In 2022, nearly half of the world population (48 per cent), or 3.83 billion people, lived in poverty," the report said.

title: Senegal storms off field in penalty protest, then returns to win mad AFCON final
text:
Senegal stormed off the field in protest at a penalty awarded against them before returning to beat hosts Morocco 1-0 after extra time and win the Africa Cup of Nations amid farcical scenes in Sunday's final.

Midfielder Pape Gueye netted the 94th-minute winner after Morocco's star player Brahim Diaz had squandered the chance to win it for the home side by fluffing the last-gasp penalty in normal time following a 14-minute delay.

Senegal coach Pape Bouna Thiaw ordered his players off and it was talisman Sadio Mane who persuaded them to return.

The penalty was awarded following a VAR check by Congolese referee Jean-Jacques Ndala after Diaz had been tugged to the ground by Senegal full-back El Hadji Malick Diouf while defending a corner five minutes into stoppage time.

Officials and players jostled with each other while the referee consulted the touchline screen and again when Senegal walked off.

Once the players returned to the field, Diaz inexplicably tried a Panenka-style chip and his weak penalty sailed tamely into the arms of Senegal goalkeeper Edouard Mendy.

Senegal's players left the field in protest of a penalty awarded to Morocco. (Reuters: Amr Abdallah Dalsh)

Senegal's actions will be seen as a major blight on an otherwise successful tournament, although defeat continued Morocco's poor record in the tournament, which it only previously won 50 years ago.

Senegal, which has won twice in the last three editions, handed top-ranked Morocco its first defeat in 27 internationals.

Gueye's powerful shot gave Morocco goalkeeper Yassine Bounou no chance but he was forced into several other key saves, as was his counterpart Mendy in an end-to-end match.

Senegal's every move was jeered by an ear-splitting cacophony of whistles from the 66,526-strong crowd, but they were undaunted as they took the game to Morocco.

They should have been behind midway through the first half when Idrissa Gana Gueye, captaining the team in place of the suspended Kalidou Koulibaly, lost possession to allow Ayoub El Kaabi to burst away on goal, but by the time he passed to Ismael Saibari his frontline partner was offside.

The energy-sapping pace of the game, with furious pressing and frenzied chasing, saw mistakes creep in with Morocco caught flat by Nicolas Jackson's 38th-minute pass to Iliman Ndiaye, whose shot was saved by Bounou.

Senegal celebrates victory in the AFCON final. (Reuters: Amr Abdallah Dalsh)

El Kaabi had a glaring miss in the 58th minute, steering Bilal El Khannouss' curling delivery from the right narrowly wide of the goal when it looked easier to score.

Senegal had the ball in the net two minutes into stoppage time in a goalmouth scramble, but Abdoulaye Seck had pushed Achraf Hakimi in the build-up and it was ruled out.

"We are really disappointed for all the Moroccan people," said their coach Walid Regragui.

"When you get a penalty in the last minute, you can see victory very close, but in the end football catches up with you.

"We congratulate Senegal, even if what we showed of African football was disappointing, given everything that happened when the penalty was awarded."

Reuters

title: Live: Aussie comeback queen beams after pulling off first-round upset
text:
Marina Stakusic is in pursuit of a first ever Australian Open main draw win, clinching the opening set in fashion against Queenslander Priscilla Hon, 6-1.

Stakusic is using the court well, and has come out truly firing.

Hon on the other hand, has looked a bit nervous and anxious — you're playing your home major, your friends and family are in the stands and you've been given a wildcard, so you're very aware of all those things.

It's actually been a while since she has started directly in the main draw of a grand slam. Usually, Hon comes through qualifying but now she's come in cold (not many matches under her belt) where there's more excitement, and that's a challenge in itself.

Hon left the court at the end of the first set so hopefully she'll come out with a bit of a different mind set in the second set.

title: A small reminder of home anchors Australia's Olympic ice dancers
text:
Australian ice dancers Jason Chan and Holly Harris both looked off camera as our online conversation drew to a close.

We were talking while the pair were in Chan's hometown of Montreal, Canada, where Australia's number one-ranked ice dancing team are based for the majority of the year.

It appeared there was an interloper to our conversation, albeit an adorable one.

"This is Piper," Harris said, making the introductions as Chan grabbed a toy poodle — wearing a jumper to deal with the autumnal Canadian chill — and held her up to the camera.

"Sorry for her impoliteness," Harris added.

Piper's silent interruption was far from impolite.

Indeed, so often are these two away from their home — every few weeks during the season — Piper, understandably inquisitive, quite reasonably decided she wanted to join in.

Piper is a small reminder of home for Holly Harris. (Supplied: Hollu Harris)

Just the week before we spoke late last year, the pair were in the Tblisi Ice Palace, Georgia, skating at the Trialeti Trophy International Skating Union (ISU) Challenger Series event.

They finished second in the former Soviet republic, their first medal at ISU Challenger level.

A couple of weeks before that, they were in Beijing, earning Australia a quota spot for the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympic Games and fulfilling a life-long dream — confirmed today when they were named in the Olympic squad.

Harris and Chan, along with figure skaters Anastasiia Golubeva and Hektor Giotopoulos, received the honour of becoming the first four athletes officially named to Australia's Olympic team for the 2026 Games.

Competing at an Olympics is a considerable reward, but the life of an Australian winter sport athlete can still be tough.

A lack of facilities and opportunity means Australia's Winter Olympic hopefuls often have to travel far and travel often to get their chance.

Piper, named after the eastern Sydney suburb of Point Piper, represents a small, desperately sweet reminder of home for Harris, whose dreams of representing Australia at the Winter Olympics have taken her halfway around the world.

It's a dream that is just days away from finally being realised.

The challenges of finding a dance partner

Holly Harris and Jason Chan say picking a partner for ice dance is like dating. (Getty Images: Corbis/Tim Clayton)

Harris moved to Canada when she was just 16, a teenager making a painful yet essential sacrifice to pursue her dreams.

And events that met her when she arrived as a young woman in a foreign land couldn't have helped whatever anxiety she may have felt about moving away from everything she knew.

"I was actually moving to Montreal with a different partner," Harris said.

"And they ended up, really last minute, not coming.

"So I was 16 years old, just moved to a new country and found myself there, like, 'Oh, my God, what am I gonna do? My life's over.'

"But I was still really determined to keep training, to achieve my goals, so I was like, 'No, I'll skate by myself here.'

"And then Jason was here looking for a partner, so it was kind of just like fate, almost.

"We tried out for two weeks and then we were like, 'OK, yeah, let's give it a go' — and it ended up being pretty good."

Pretty good is one way of looking at it.

By finishing second at the Skate to Milano event, Harris and Chan — who took Australian citizenship in 2021 in order to compete with Harris — earned Australia a slot at the Winter Olympics in ice dancing, the country's first since Danielle O'Brien and Greg Merriman competed at Sochi in 2014.

Earning a quota spot did not guarantee Harris and Chan a place at the Games themselves.

But as Australia's premier pairing, it was always going to be tough to overlook them.

Dance or figure skating?

There are some subtle differences between the skills involved in pairs figure skating and ice dance. (Getty Images: Fred Lee)

Ice dance is one of four figure skating disciplines that will be contested at the Winter Olympics.

There are solo competitions for men and women, while there is also a pairs competition, separate to ice dance.

Australia has also earned a pairs slot at the Games in Milano-Torino: Hektor Giotopoulos-Moore and Anastasia Golubeva will represent Australia in this discipline.

So what's the difference?

"The pairs and the ice dance sometimes get confused together because we're both duos," Chan explained.

"But the pairs do a little bit more acrobatic tricks. They lift a bit more above the head, and then they do all the jumps together.

"For us it's really about what the essence of the skating is, the dance and the skating skills."

Harris took over.

"Skating skills, composition, performance, we also have lifts but they have different rules and requirements," she said.

"I would say ice dance is really about the whole package. We really want to tell a story on the ice, every aspect, every second of the programme.

"The goal is to look perfectly put together; you're always in character and the costumes and storytelling is really complete."

Holly Harris and Jason Chan had to develop a close relationship in a short period of time. (Getty Images: CorbisTim Clayton)

The fact that Chan and Harris have developed the habit of finishing each other's conversations fits remarkably with the foundations of friendship that have had to develop for them to dance effectively together.

"People joke that it's kind of like dating," Harris said of how hard it was to select a dance partner.

"You have to try out, decide if it's gonna work out or not," she added before Chan chipped in.

"There's so many factors that go into it," he said.

"There is our personalities, if we mesh well, if our skating styles mesh well."

The timing of their partnership's beginning was less than ideal. COVID plunged the world into lockdown just as the pair were getting used to each other.

"We were stuck in our homes, doing Zoom calls with our coaching team, doing Pilates on Zoom, ballet workouts, everything," Harris said.

"I feel like it was like that for three months maybe. We slowly started going into the rink, they would find ice somewhere, we'd have to wear masks, there were a lot of rules and restrictions, and then eventually comps just kept getting cancelled and cancelled.

Holly Harris and Jason Chan competed in the ISU World Figure Skating Championships together for the first time in 2021 in Stockholm. (Getty Images: Linnea Rheborg)

"So eventually … we both went back [to Australia] and we ended up staying there for like six months."

However, the Zoom calls continued.

"We had lessons over Zoom, we prepared for our first world championships together via Zoom," Harris said, recounting the way their fledgling partnership had to overcome the issues to prepare for the 2021 Stockholm World Championships, which doubled as the final qualifier for the COVID-affected Beijing Games.

Despite those "less than ideal conditions", Harris and Chan were tantalisingly close to reaching the Games, being named as one of the alternates, ready to step up in case of injury.

"We were pretty close," Harris said. "We really were hoping [we would get there]. But it was very early in our partnership, so it was a stretch.

"But I think we did our best — we were alternates, so that hope [of getting a chance] remained throughout the last Games, so that was a little painful.

"I even got accreditation as an alternate. I don't know why, but that kind of made it a little more painful.

"This time it turned out differently."

It really did.

Olympics 'My whole world'

Holly Harris and Jason Chan earned their quota spot for the 2026 Olympics at the ISU Skate to Milano Figure Skating Qualifier in Beijing. (Getty Images: VCG/Tang Xinyu)

Chan and Harris set a personal-best score of 183.50 in Beijing's Skate to Milano event to secure their spot at the Games.

"It would have been nice [to qualify in 2022], but we were just so new as a team," Harris said.

"I think the experience would have just been so different and having achieved this goal in the way that we did this time, it was very transformative for us as athletes.

"I really feel like this made me become a stronger athlete, made me prioritise everything so much more.

"It's obviously my whole world, you know, it always has been, but not qualifying at worlds was just so gut-wrenching that it really put our butts in gear and we just really went for it.

"I knew I did everything I could … to achieve this goal, so going to the qualifier I was super confident.

"So I think, in those ways, it made us stronger and turned out for the better."

Holly Harris and Jason Chan say it was emotional to qualify for a quota spot at the Games. (Getty Images: VCG/Tang Xinyu)

Harris said that she was "crying all evening" after the pair secured their spot at the Games in China.

"I've lain up in bed at night as a little girl, dreaming of this moment, envisioning the Olympics and how it will be," she said.

"All of that just washes over you. You're almost in disbelief and it's just like, there's so much relief that you've finally achieved this goal that you've been waiting for.

"I was just so emotional … it was one of the best moments of my life."

Chan said seeing the scores come up and understanding what it meant was "surreal".

"Because it's the culmination of all the hard work and the journey," he said.

"For it to actually come to fruition is pretty amazing."

In all three competitions since the 2025 World Championships in March, Harris and Chan have finished on the podium.

The pair will compete in a handful of competitions before the Olympics to fine-tune their routine — including in China this week at the Four Continents competition — before heading to Italy in February for the realisation of their dream and the latest stop on what has been an incredible journey so far.

Holly Harris and Jason Chan set a new personal best in Beijing at the start of this Olympic season. (Getty Images: Corbis/Tim Clayton)

"It's really satisfying to see that finally … things are coming together," Harris said.

"We worked so hard in the last six months from worlds and I really do feel like that's paying off.

"We just made sure we were ready really early this season and that's really helping us. So I think that's another lesson for the future seasons ahead, because that really just helped us grow faster this season."

Chan noted that although the hard work had never stopped, the momentum provided by a series of good results had been invaluable heading into their first Olympics together.

"The process is the same," Chan said.

"We just focus on improving every day … coming into the rink and focusing on what to do and doing our jobs.

"The process is the same from worlds last March but now we feel like there's a momentum coming up and going into Milan, which is exciting."

title: Accidental conservation success story under threat by government plan
text:
Conservationists say ponds that have become home to endangered migratory birds are slated for removal under state government plans to develop Sydney's north-west fringe.

Local birdwatchers say the former waste ponds of a shuttered abattoir have become an ideal habitat for short-legged wader birds, including the endangered Australian painted snipe and the vulnerable sharp-tailed sandpiper.

Birdwatchers are alarmed about the planned removal of the ponds in Riverstone in Sydney's north-west. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

Avian enthusiasts say the ponds also host birds that migrate as far as Antarctica and Alaska, such as the Pacific golden plover and the curlew sandpiper, which is considered critically endangered both nationally and in New South Wales.

The state government plans to rezone the currently vacant privately owned land for light industrial use, and replace the ponds with 57 hectares of wetlands, 18 hectares of which would be shallow wetland area.

The vulnerable sharp-tailed sandpiper has been spotted at the ponds. (Supplied: Mark Fuller)

Birdwatchers say the ponds are ideal because they are above ground level and flood-proof, while other wetlands in Sydney such as Homebush, and the mooted replacements, would be flood-prone.

"It's the last place that they've really got that they can still find suitable conditions," veteran bird watcher Mark Fuller said.

" When it goes, these birds will have nowhere and there's a good chance that a lot of them will die. "

Mark Fuller says the rare migratory birds will have nowhere to go. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

Endangered green and golden bell frogs have also been heard calling in one of the ponds by a field survey done for the private landowners, Garfield Pastoral Holdings and Leamac Property Group.

The new ponds to replace the old Riverstone Meatworks dams would be established before their removal.

However, Mr Fuller says the proposed areas are close to creeks, which would make them flood-prone and often unusable to the rare short-legged birds.

Maureen Harper says the government should turn the ponds into a birdwatching tourism destination. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

"We're really down to the very last few remaining pieces of suitable wetland and that's not only in Australia," Mr Fuller said.

"Riverstone Meatworks [ponds] has got the runs on the board as far as attracting all the rare birds.

" I'm very sceptical that they could create anything as good as what they've already got. "

Marsden Park local and bird enthusiast Maureen Harper says the replacement ponds would also feature a high dirt wall around them, which would take away the birds' ability to spot predators.

Ms Harper would like to see the state government develop the ponds into a birdwatching tourism destination.

"It's the perfect opportunity to do some proper conservation," Ms Harper said.

" Don't throw it away, because nobody's ever going to replace it. "

Dumping ground gets a new life

The dams were built in the 70s to be used as an effluent dumping ground by the Riverstone Meatworks.

They were built above ground and flood-proof so the waste would not pollute the nearby environment, including a pair of creeks that feed into the Hawkesbury River.

Birdwatchers say endangered Australian painted snipe have been seen in the wetland. (Supplied: Edwin Vella)

After the abattoir closed in 1994, the dams made for an ideal habitat because of their distance from human activity, protection against predators and their shallow depth ideal for short-legged wading birds.

Conservationists say the waste product has promoted the growth of microbial invertebrates that the migratory birds feed off.

MP says road project will doom the ponds

Before entering politics, Riverstone MP Warren Kirby wrote a lengthy online blog post about the wetlands, referring to them as an "oasis virtually nobody knew existed".

In the post, Mr Kirby questioned redeveloping the ponds as "to pave (avian) paradise and put up a housing lot".

Warren Kirby says a necessary road project will render the ponds unsuitable for the migratory birds. (ABC News: Isobel Roe)

Mr Kirby said part of the development includes a major road running near the artificial ponds that he says will make the ponds unattractive to migratory birds.

"A problem with that is all of the housing that's been built up all around it, that Bandon Road corridor is actually a really vital link," Mr Kirby said.

"The only way to prevent turning the migratory birds … off [the ponds] … is to get rid of both Bandon Road and essentially three-quarters of the Marsden Park North development."

He said while he doesn't support the ponds' removal, he understands the necessity of developing the area given the scale of housing development in neighbouring areas.

The state government plans to replace the current ponds (red) with larger habitats closer to nearby creeks. (Supplied: NSW Department of Planning, Housing and Infrastructure)

"The cost of that inaction at this point in time when all of the other residential development and all the other work has been done all around the place.

"It's not really a viable solution to say no."

Mr Kirby said the proposed alternative ponds would result in better, broader environmental outcomes for the area.

Jobs hub planned for new growth area

The state government announced the rezoning of the ponds and surrounding area as part of the Marsden Park North north-west growth area.

When the rezoning was announced in November, the state government said the 1,200-hectare area would support about 3,900 new jobs and 960 new homes.

NSW Planning Minister Paul Scully said the government was seeking public feedback on the plans until January 30.

"All submissions will be carefully considered to inform the final plans for the Marsden Park North precinct, including the settlement ponds," Mr Scully said.

title: Man suffers spinal injures in 40 metre cliff fall at Melbourne beach
text:
A man is in hospital after falling about 40 metres down a cliff at a beach in Melbourne's south.

The 18-year-old suffered spinal, arm and leg injuries after falling onto a ledge at Half Moon Bay in Black Rock about 8:30pm on Sunday.

Fire Rescue Victoria's (FRV) high angle rescue team joined State Emergency Service crews and paramedics as they attempted to reach the man.

FRV Senior Station Officer Tyson Scurrah said the ledge was about 5 metres above the ground, which posed a further challenge for crews trying to treat him and bring him down safely.

"We were required to go down there and set up in very difficult terrain," he told ABC Radio Melbourne.

"It's all sandstone so nothing too stable for us to anchor our ropes off."

He said the teams rigged up a system that allowed paramedics to stabilise the patient and then lower him to the sand and walk him out along the beach.

" He's a very lucky person. "

The rescue took about half an hour.

The man was then transferred to hospital in a stable condition.

The night-time beach rescue posed a challenge for rescuers. (ABC News)

The rescue happened on the same day a man aged in his 20s suffered serious injuries after falling from a a cliff at Mount Martha, about 50 kilometres to the south of Black Rock.

Rescue crews were called to The Pillars rock formations about 5:15pm.

He was flown to the Royal Melbourne Hospital in a serious but stable condition.

Just days earlier, a woman fell off a cliff in Beaumaris — a suburb neighbouring Black Rock.

She remains in a critical condition in hospital.

There were also a number of similar rescues at beaches in Victoria in December.

Lifesaving Victoria rescues a paddleboarder who got into difficulty at Carrum Beach on Sunday. (Supplied: Carrum Surf Life Saving Club)

Meanwhile, lifesavers carried out multiple rescues of paddleboarders around Melbourne yesterday as unusual easterly winds caught beachgoers unawares.

Carrum Surf Lifesavers pulled seven paddleboarders back to shore and Lifesaving Victoria's watercraft rescued another two.

The club's Ben Rooks said there were also multiple rescues at neighbouring Chelsea, Aspendale and Bonbeach.

"People would go out within what they felt was their comfort zone and then suddenly realise, a bit like when you go for a bike ride and you've got a tail wind when you go out but then you've got a headwind when on the way back and suddenly you realise you're struggling a bit," Mr Rooks said.

He said most of the rescues were people aged in their 20s but there were some children rescued after drifting out into Port Phillip.

"If you've got children in the water, always keep them within arm's length so you can grab them if something happens," he said.

title: Bushfire south of Adelaide started by vehicle, CFS believes
text:
A bushfire that has ripped through more than 600 hectares and destroyed at least two family homes is believed to have been started by an "accidental ignition" from a vehicle, the Country Fire Service (CFS) says.

Hundreds of firefighters have been battling theTooperang fire which is burning near Mount Compass and remains uncontrolled.

The fire broke out about 4:30pm on Sunday and has so far blackened about 640 hectares of grass and scrub, the CFS said.

The fire has burned through more than 600 hectares. (Facebook: Willunga Country Fire Service)

A watch and act message has been issued for an area including Tooperang, Nangkita, Mount Jagged and Mosquito Hill, with the CFS advising residents to take action.

Water bombers have been battling the fire, which the CFS said had impacted an area between Nangkita Road and Cleland Gully Road, "including structures and farm sheds".

Dozens of firefighters and trucks have been involved in the CFS response. (ABC News: Caroline Horn)

CFS deputy state controller Brenton Hastie confirmed at least three structures had been lost, including sheds and "possibly a house".

"I have no doubt in addition to the three structures we're able to confirm, that smaller assets — whether that be motorhome or smaller sheds — that toll would unfortunately rise," he told ABC Radio Adelaide.

"Crews were faced with 10 ignitions across a stretch of road yesterday."

The property losses include the motorhome of Natasha Price and the home of Isaac Selfe.

Hundreds of firefighters have been battling the Tooperang fire burning since Sunday. (Facebook: Willunga Country Fire Service)

Mr Hastie said the weather conditions today were "more favourable" than they were on Sunday and they were likely to downgrade the fire from a watch and act later today.

He also said there was a "high level of confidence" that the fire was caused by an "accidental ignition" from a vehicle.

"A vehicle travelling the road — whether that's [a] mechanical issue or something else. But we don't believe this was arson as we initially feared this fire started," Mr Hastie said.

The fire has ripped through more than 600 hectares. (Supplied: Courtney Christie)

ABC reporter Caroline Horn was in the area early this morning and said she could see burnt-out paddocks that were "still smouldering", as well as other damage.

"Unfortunately there is a structure that you can see that's been destroyed. I don't know whether it's a shed or a house," she told ABC Radio Adelaide.

The CFS said more than 200 firefighters supported by more than 60 trucks and other agencies including the Metropolitan Fire Service had worked into the night to reduce the fire's spread.

A fire reconnaissance aircraft equipped with an infrared camera for detecting hot spots flew over the fire ground earlier this morning.

The CFS said it showed about 640 hectares had so far been burnt — up from an earlier figure of 450.

The extent of the damage is still becoming known. (Supplied: Courtney Christie)

Road closures are in place in the area.

Local state MP David Basham, who used to have a dairy farm in the area, said he was helping a local property owner move "a fair number of cattle out of the way" well into the night.

"It certainly was a challenging situation," he said.

"We were sort of just trying to defend and waiting for it to come out of the scrub and trying to put it out before it ran across the grassland, which would have been linked to another lot of scrub, so it was a fantastic job by those 20 local farmers up there."

The Tooperang fire near Mount Compass broke out on Sunday and burned through the night. (Supplied: Courtney Christie)

Alpaca farmer Chris Williams said he had swiftly put his bushfire action plan into effect.

"One of the biggest problems this year is there's just so much tall grass around," he said.

"I rang a couple of neighbours just to make sure they were aware of everything, because the problem on a hot day is you can be sitting inside your house with your curtains drawn and air conditioner on and you're totally oblivious to what's happening outside."

The CFS said firefighters were working in difficult terrain including plantations. (ABC News: Caroline Horn)

Earlier today, CFS state duty officer Ben Pettman said crews were working to stop the spread to Mount Magnificent and Cox Scrub conservation parks.

"Thankfully at this stage the fire hasn't entered either of those parks and crews are working really hard to contain the fire and limit the spread so it doesn't impact those areas," Mr Pettman said.

"The winds have kept the fire up overnight and the fire has continued to slowly burn through that inaccessible terrain — our crews have been working really hard overnight to try and implement control lines around this fire.

"The fire has continued to move in a south-westerly direction towards Cleland Gully Road. However, our crews have continued to hold the fire overnight but it is still burning in those inaccessible areas."

title: Brisbane 'eyesore' remains as government reneges on construction date
text:
A derelict Brisbane block occupied by squatters and vandals will remain abandoned indefinitely as a government construction project stalls with no explanation.

It comes after the Queensland government evicted shopkeepers along Boundary Road in Coopers Plains so construction could begin on an overpass in mid-2025.

That construction never happened, and now the Department of Transport and Main Roads (TMR) says it has no timeline for when it expects work to begin.

The overpass is a joint project by all three levels of government and featured heavily as a federal election promise on the 2022 campaign trail.

The Coopers Plains overpass has been promised by successive governments since the 1980s.

A broken promise

Suresh Chandra says he now feels unsafe in his own neighbourhood. ( )

Suresh Chandra, who lives down the road from the abandoned "eyesore", said residents felt disillusioned.

"The promise has been broken to the local people," Mr Chandra said.

"Those poor shopkeepers have stopped earning money and their livelihoods have been lost."

Mr Chandra said it was "scary" living near the site due to the trespassers he had seen hanging around the abandoned shopping malls and business centre.

The project was supposed to remove the level crossing at Coopers Plains and replace it with an overpass with an elevated three-way intersection and pedestrian-cycle lanes.

The Coopers Plains shopping centre is regularly vandalised. The shop windows have been bashed in by vandals. (ABC Radio Brisbane: Kenji Sato) The Coopers Plains Business Centre has attracted squatters and vandals. ( ) The business centre lies empty and abandoned. (ABC Radio Brisbane: Kenji Sato) The Coopers Plains Shopping Centre site has been sitting abandoned since August. The Coopers Plains Shopping Centre regularly attracts squatters. (ABC Radio Brisbane: Kenji Sato) The notorious Boundary Road level crossing. ( ) Boundary Road is a major thoroughfare. (ABC Radio Brisbane: Kenji Sato)

A spokesperson for Federal Transport Minister Catherine King said they were working towards a start date.

"The Boundary Road Level Crossing Removal was a 2022 election commitment and remains a priority for the Australian government," the spokesperson said.

"Residents of Coopers Plains experience some of the longest delays due to the level crossing gates being down and this will only get worse when the Cross River Rail project is completed.

"The Australian government remains willing to work with the Queensland government to ensure early works can commence without further delay, and to understand what is required to deliver the project in full."

The spokesperson did not respond to 612 ABC Radio Brisbane's questions on what caused the delay.

No explanations given

Rowan Gray says the level crossing removal will reduce delays for train passengers, cyclists, and pedestrians. ( )

Better Transport Queensland president Rowan Gray said this was a serious lack of transparency from the state and federal governments.

"It's really disappointing that the Queensland government and TMR haven't been up-front with the public on what's causing this delay," Mr Gray said.

"It makes the travelling public a lot more sceptical of whether we're going to have a successful Cross River Rail opening or whether we're going to have a successful 2032 Olympic Games."

Mr Gray said the level crossing removal would drastically improve commute times for public transport users, cyclists, pedestrians and drivers.

He said it was crucial to remove the Boundary Road level crossing before the Cross River Rail project was completed, since it intersected with the rapidly growing Gold Coast Line.

A TMR spokesperson said the project remained a priority.

"The Queensland government remains committed to the project with procurement and construction timeframes subject to further negotiation with the Australian government."

title: Old tyres could help build tougher roads for the NT's extreme climate
text:
Repurposing old tyres may be the key to building stronger, longer-lasting roads to handle the Northern Territory's harsh climate, say researchers.

About 400 tonnes of tyres are discarded by Darwin residents and commercial operators every year.

They are dropped off at Shoal Bay Waste Management Facility, stored, then sent interstate or overseas for recycling.

Crumb rumber from old tyres, along with plastics from shrink wrap and shampoo bottles are among the materials being repurposed. (ABC News: Tilda Colling)

But researchers at Charles Darwin University (CDU) are investigating whether recycled materials, including granulated crumb rubber from ground-up tyres and plastics, can instead be used to improve NT roads.

CDU has been collaborating with the NT Department of Logistics and Infrastructure to test this theory since late 2021.

PhD student with the university, Ramin Shahbazi, said flexible materials — which bend and flex under the weight of traffic — were often used in the road construction process.

Roads in the NT face some of the harshest weather conditions in the country, from blistering heat to drenching rains. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

But he said a different approach was needed in places such as the NT, where extreme weather conditions proved challenging.

"When we have a flexible pavement made of asphalt, it's constantly changing when it's exposed to hot weather and moisture from the rain," he said.

"We wanted to try and replace regular material that was being used in the pavements with recycled alternatives — but try to keep the performance as it is, or also maybe improve it."

Ramin Shahbazi says flexible pavements made of asphalt can crack under the pressure of extreme weather in the NT. (ABC News: Tilda Colling)

Reclaimed asphalt, crushed glass, recycled concrete and crumb rubber from tyres and plastics are being tested with the aim of improving road durability, a Department of Logistics and Infrastructure spokesperson explained.

Senior CDU engineering lecturer and PhD supervisor, Ali Rajabipour, said both council budgets and the environment would benefit from giving the alternative materials a new life.

Tyres waiting to be recycled at the Shoal Bay Waste Management Facility in Karama. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

"Some countries [burn tyre waste], that's not the best way to use crumb rubber … it produces fumes, which are not very healthy," he said.

Dr Rajabipour said the NT could save about $2 million a year by recycling materials dumped in landfill.

Ali Rajabipour says the NT could save millions of dollars by repurposing waste. (ABC News: Tilda Colling)

Circular economy is the goal

The City of Darwin has committed to a "circular economy", where waste materials are reused and recycled.

But the council's head of environment and waste, Nick Fewster, said achieving that goal could be logistically challenging.

Nick Fewster says materials are often sent overseas for processing. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

Mr Fewster said repurposing disused tyres locally would reduce the environmental impact made by freight activity as transporting waste — including sending materials off-shore for processing — produced carbon emissions.

"We're all about diverting waste from landfill and reusing materials where possible as part of the circular economy," he said.

But waste management is only part of the equation.

Nik Kleine and Nick Fewster inspecting the recycling facility in Karama. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

Council's head of infrastructure, Nik Kleine, said Darwin roads faced unique weather challenges across both the NT's wet and dry seasons which could shorten the life span of road surfaces.

"You'll see cracking, you'll see potholes," he said.

Mr Kleine said the CDU trial was an opportunity to give new life to products that would otherwise be sent to landfill.

Tyres that are no longer roadworthy can be repurposed into new products. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

What happens next?

If the research proves successful, Mr Kleine said City of Darwin would consider trialling the recycled materials in local roads.

"It's done through a tender process … and [this project] would definitely tick the sustainability and environment box," he said.

Filippo Giustozzi, professor of civil and infrastructure engineering at RMIT University, said the investigation aligned with existing evidence on the benefits of crumb rubber in asphalt — but warned its effectiveness would need to be proven under territory conditions.

"Challenging environments like the Northern Territory — with extreme heat, UV exposure and intense tropical rainfall — require site-specific testing to confirm durability, ageing behaviour and moisture resistance over time," he said.

The rubber from old tyres can be recycled. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

Professor Giustozzi also said recycled plastics were still relatively new in road construction and often needed to be combined with traditional materials to ensure long-term performance.

The NT Department of Logistics and Infrastructure said laboratory testing was about 75 per cent complete, with more than 8,000 tests conducted so far.

Road trials using recycled materials are expected to begin early this year.

title: A new CBD grill serving wagyu steak frites for less than $30
text:
Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime.

1 / 7 Steak frites made with Angus rostbiff at Common Cuts, a new city grill. Alex Coppel 2 / 7 Inside the Russell Streett steakhouse. Alex Coppel 3 / 7 Steak frites start at $28.50. Alex Coppel 4 / 7 Steak frites made with wagyu flank. Alex Coppel 5 / 7 The cheeseburger with extra wagyu. Alex Coppel 6 / 7 Yorkshire pudding with padron peppers. Alex Coppel 7 / 7 DJ Ajeet inside the restaurant. Alex Coppel Previous Slide Next Slide

Steakhouse$$$$

At Common Cuts, opposite Old Melbourne Gaol on Russell Street in the CBD, it’s all about the sub-$30 steak frites. Diners choose between a 220-gram piece of Black Diamond wagyu flank or a 300-gram O’Connor Angus rostbiff cooked over charcoal. Fries are included in the $28.50 dish, but sauces cost an additional $4.50.

Beyond the two entry-level steak frites, there are seven more options priced between $45 and $185 from various producers. A further three O’Connor steaks, dry-aged for four weeks by supplier Vic’s Meat, go up to $220 for a one-kilogram T-bone. Sauces go beyond the typical bearnaise or red wine jus. Charred spring onion and malt butter, mustard and horseradish, and chimichurri are among the six choices.

The menu also includes steak tartare made with a mix of Angus rump, rostbiff and tenderloin, plus a decadent wagyu lasagne garnished with bone marrow. A 180-gram cheeseburger on a Martin’s potato roll ($28.50) can be upgraded to a wagyu-on-wagyu blowout ($48.50) where 85 grams of sliced A5 Japanese wagyu are laid on top of the melted cheese.

title: Sydney Fish Market opening LIVE updates: Foodies, shoppers flock to new $836 million site at Blackwattle Bay
text:
Crowds are being told to either wait in line or “come back later” as the new fish market officially reaches capacity.

Wardens were seen herding the queue and telling visitors to “come back this evening” as a long line of patrons snaked down Bridge Road.

Just hours after opening, many visitors have been told to turn around and come back later. Credit: Wolter Peeters

Alex Jensen, who took a train and tram to the soak in the market’s opening day said it was disappointing.

“All we were told is that it’s full and we either have to queue up or come back later,” he said. “It’s disappointing because we made the trip especially to be here.”

People line up to get into the new Sydney Fish Market. Credit: Dominic Lorrimer

As of 12.45pm the queue time to enter the market was running at 20 to 30 minutes.

Visitors are being told by fish market staff that the space is at capacity, and that no one else will be allowed in just five hours into the grand opening day.

Garner and Michelle Annett made a reservation at a restaurant inside the fish market, but have been waiting in line for more than 40 minutes. They were told by staff that markets had reached capacity.

“The restaurant is ringing and saying ‘where are you?’” Michelle said.

“They’ve said they’re going to hold [the table] but we’ll see how that goes,” Garner said.

title: Australian Open LIVE 2026: De Minaur begins Open quest against American Mackenzie McDonald; Gauff, Swiatek, Djokovic in action
text:
Both tennis figures are Asian-American, both call California home and both have made big inroads in tennis at a young age.

Rising star Learner Tien, who shocked Daniil Medvedev last year at the Australian Open on the way to the fourth round, joined forces with Michael Chang midway through 2025, signing the American great as his new coach.

Learner Tien in action. Credit: Getty Images

Tien, 20, had another breakout season last year, improving his ranking to as high as world No.26, winning his first ATP title and ruling the roost at the Next Generation ATP Finals, which showcases the game’s young stars.

The left-hander is happy with his progression, delivering on a goal to win his first title before his 20th birthday, and agrees that last year’s second-round win over Medvedev – a near five-hour match that finished in the early hours – was a significant moment.

Coach and former star player Michael Chang. Credit: Getty Images

“That match actually got me into the Top 100. I started to feel more and more like I belonged,” said Learner, who has Vietnamese heritage, ahead of his Australian Open first-round match against countryman Marcos Giron this afternoon.

Chang, a former world No.2 and the youngest man in history to win a singles major – the 1989 French Open title – doesn’t want to put a ceiling on Learner’s potential this year.

“For me personally … if you look at this past year, Learner’s beaten more Top 10 guys than anybody else apart from Carlos [Alcaraz] and Jannik [Sinner],” Chang said.

“When you’ve beaten Top 10 guys … that should give you some confidence.

“For me as a coach, for me personally, I have that belief in him as a person [and] in his game – obviously he’s still learning a lot, he’s still growing a lot, he’s still improving.

“But I think it’s been pretty incredible for him to go through a first full season and accomplish what he has accomplished in such a short period of time.”

Learner and Chang’s paths first crossed a little over a year ago in Hong Kong. As they learnt about each other last year, joining forces seemed the right choice.

“Some aspects (of our relationship and similarities) makes it a little bit easier. We can talk about things that are in Orange County. He knows what I’m talking about, and I know what he’s talking about,” Chang said.

“The one thing that actually has been quite nice is that Learner’s very cerebral, so he’s a thinker out there (on the court), which is very similar to how my mind works.

“I’ve always been a little bit before [inclined to] … over-share about different things, whether it was, you know, technically or strategically.

Learner Tien, 19, caused a massive upset by ousting Medvedev in 2025. Credit: AP

“But Learner doesn’t have an issue with that. He absorbs things very well, he understands things very well. So that’s been refreshing for me as a coach because I don’t have to hold back.”

Tien wasn’t even born when Chang retired in 2003, seven years after he lost the Australian Open final to Boris Becker.

Tien said his agent did most of the “heavy lifting” when he secured Chang. “I think it’s been a great fit so far,” he said.

title: Storm’s opponent was ranked 327 places higher than her. She won anyway
text:
When Australian Storm Hunter ruptured her Achilles in April 2024, she didn’t know if she’d ever be able to return to her home slam.

She was doubles world No.3, had won six singles matches in a row (including qualifying) in Melbourne earlier that year and was preparing to represent Australia at the Billie Jean King Cup when she suffered the potentially career-ending injury.

Storm Hunter celebrates victory at Melbourne Park. Credit: Eddie Jim

But on Monday afternoon, in front of a roaring crowd at Kia Arena, Hunter was an Australian Open winner again, defeating Spain’s Jessica Bouzas Maneiro 6-4, 6-4.

It was a win against the odds – Bouzas Maneiro is ranked 327 places higher than Hunter.

title: Larvotto NSW antimony production gathers pace as growth options build
text:
Larvotto Resources is fast emerging as a near-term critical minerals producer, with refurbishment works and underground mining activities at its Hillgrove antimony–gold project in NSW on track and, importantly, on budget, ahead of a return to production by mid-year.

Alongside Hillgrove, the company is lining up its next growth moves, eyeing a rare earths opportunity in Western Australia and a promising copper play near Mt Isa in Queensland as potential next chapters in the company’s expansion story.

Anaiwan cultural mural at Larvotto Resources’ Hillgrove Hub. The artwork will feature on the Hillgrove high-vis work shirts.

In NSW, meanwhile, Larvotto has wasted no time shifting its high-grade gold and antimony mine into execution mode, ripping out and dispatching processing plant equipment for refurbishment, while upgrading site services.

Underground mining has also restarted, with contractor PYBAR now fully mobilised. Rehabilitation of more than 2,500 square metres of underground drives is now complete and waste haulage is underway ahead of ore development blasting expected in early February.

title: Lygon Street’s last butcher has a new owner with a familiar name
text:
Advertisement

Eating outMelbourne icon Lygon Street’s last butcher has a new owner with a familiar name Customers of the legendary Donati’s butcher shop in Carlton feared the end was nigh when its founder announced his retirement. But their prayers may have been answered by a buyer who wants business as usual. Emma Breheny Updated January 19, 2026 ,first published January 19, 2026 Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

Donati’s Fine Meats, a fixture of Lygon Street since 1972, will continue to trade as a butcher shop with a new owner – who has a name familiar to many on the strip – taking the reins from founder Leo Donati, who is retiring. When the 77-year-old Donati announced his plans to sell the business and retire late last year, it sparked worry that the last butcher shop of Carlton’s Little Italy would also become history. Leo Donati and son Marcello of Donati’s butcher shop on Lygon Street, Carlton. Eddie Jim But Jamie Valmorbida, part of the family who own King & Godfree and several other businesses nearby, has purchased the shop with the intent to continue supplying pork sausages, veal and other meat to its many regular customers. Significantly, he will not be changing the name of the shop. “The shop’s already thriving. My job is to protect that,” said Valmorbida. “Over time, we think the brand has potential, and I’m excited to explore that in the future. But the focus right now is doing the fundamentals right.”

Advertisement

Donati’s reputation is for more than just excellent meat. The shop is well-known for playing classical music all day, artworks honouring cows and pigs, fresh flowers on the counter, and high-quality conversation spanning current affairs, books, composers and more. Valmorbida takes possession on January 30 and will work with Leo Donati’s son Marcello on a transition. Most of the art and Leo’s playlists come with the sale. Jamie Valmorbida (right) with King & Godfree co-director Luca Sbardella. Wayne Taylor Butcher Sam Spagnuolo, an employee of more than 20 years, will remain while Mark Glenn, executive chef of several Valmorbida venues, will oversee operations. There are plans to recruit a head butcher, and build a team of both current and past team members. “It’s impossible to replace Leo and Marcello but creating a unique service experience is going to be a priority,” Valmorbida said.

Advertisement

While he wouldn’t expand on his ideas for the shop’s future, including new products, Valmorbida said any changes would be six to 12 months away. “The beauty of Donati’s is what’s there. We’re not going to change the core, but we will try some things around the side,” he added. The sale came about when Valmorbida was picking up a ham for Christmas and Leo Donati jokingly asked if he would buy the business. “I said: ‘You’ve planted the seed’ and it was genuine. From there, it moved really quickly.” The two families have long orbited the same world of Carlton’s Lygon Street. The Valmorbida name has been linked with King & Godfree, a deli and continental grocer on the corner of Faraday Street, since 1955. In more recent years, the family’s portfolio has skewed towards hospitality, much like the rest of Lygon Street. Their businesses include rooftop bar Johnny’s Green Room, Pidapipo gelato shops across Melbourne, and restaurants within King & Godfree, which has been closed since July 2024 for further changes and will reopen in stages, beginning February.

Advertisement

Leo Donati said in a statement: “Jamie shares our values of quality, craft and a long-term commitment to the Carlton neighbourhood,” he said. “Marcello and I feel confident Donati’s is in the right hands as it moves into its next chapter.” Marcello Donati has been contacted for comment. Related Article ‘It’s not just a butcher’: Legendary Carlton shop Donati’s celebrated in its final weeks
